title: Three £10M-Plus Mansions Hit Guernsey’s Tiny Property Market This Week
text:
Three lavish mansions asking north of £10 million (US$12.3 million) on the idyllic Isle of Guernsey, a British Crown dependency in the English Channel, hit the market this week.



The three newly developed properties of vastly different architectural styles are now among the priciest homes for sale on the island tax haven, according to listing site Zoopla. Each of them also has the potential to set a price record for the rocky, wind-swept island, where the top deal ever was reportedly between £7 million and £8 million.



More: Converted Warehouse in London’s Covent Garden on the Market for £3.5M

The most extravagant of the three is a £22 million mansion called “Saint Royale”—a Rococo-inspired four-floor pile overlooking the island’s historic St. Peter Port.



It’s also around the corner from one of the island’s most famous homes, Hauteville, the former residence of exiled writer Victor Hugo and now a museum celebrating the French literary giant.



Guernsey-based architect Ccd Ltd. recently completed Saint Royale with a blend of period details and modern amenities, including a home theater, a swimming pool, a games room and a health suite, according to the listing with Savills.



The main house encompasses seven bedrooms plus two more in a separate guest house on the property. The gardens also boast an ornamental pond and enclosed “circular party room,” the agents said in a news release on Wednesday.



By contrast, Maison de La Falaise, which also listed on Tuesday, asking £17.75 million, is a glass-lined construction with eclectic inspiration, including African hunting lodges to traditional Polynesian architecture, said the listing agents.



Maison de la Falaise draws on diverse inspiration from Polynesia to African hunting lodges. Savills

Nestled in a canopy of trees and landscaping, the six-bedroom house projects a jungle vibe. It also enjoys panoramic views over the sea.



“All three properties combine a strong architectural design, superb interior finishes and stunning elevated positions offering extraordinary views,” said Richard Fox, director at Savills.



The third mansion to come online this week is an Arts and Crafts-style home on the island’s eastern coastline overlooking Fermain Bay. The six-bedroom house, dubbed La Belle Vue, includes theater and games rooms, and is surrounded by gardens.



An Arts and Crafts-style house dubbed La Belle Vue Savills

Due to Guernsey’s small size, the government limits the number of homes that can be sold to non-locals. But all three of these developer-built homes are so-called open market properties, meaning that they are legally available to anyone holding British or European Economic Area passports.

The trifecta of impressive listings this week coincides with Savills launching a residential presence on the island, Mr. Fox said. “We are absolutely delighted to have been chosen to bring three of Guernsey’s finest open market homes to the market simultaneously.”
